Award.AwardTitle: Investigation of High Strain-Rate Deformation and Failure of FCC and BCC Nanostructures
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: Nanostructures such as nanowires and nanotubes are envisioned to play a critical role in the next generation of advanced materials for energy, electronic devices, and nano-electromechanical systems. This broad technological applicability has elicited a demand for extensive characterization of the fundamental properties of nanostructures, yet previous studies have neglected to characterize these materials under high strain-rate conditions. This project involves characterizing the mechanical properties of metallic nanowires at high strain rates using transmission electron microscopy and developing new theoretical models to understand the relationship between the structure of the nanowires and their mechanical properties. This fundamental research provides opportunities to develop new educational modules on the subject of mechanical properties testing and stimulates new innovations in the design and manufacture of high performing robust nanoscale devices. As well, training of a graduate student and post-doctoral associate is an inherent part of this research.

TECHNICAL DETAILS: The goal of this research project is to explore for the first time the mechanical response of sub-150 nm-diameter metallic nanowires at high strain rates (up to 10^5 /s) to elucidate the structure-property relationships of nanostructures at high strain rates. To this end, nanowires are experimentally characterized by augmenting microelectromechanical systems (MEMS) mechanical characterization platforms with capabilities for in situ transmission electron microscopy (TEM) testing. The newly designed MEMS platforms with piezoelectric-based actuation and reduced mass are designed to attain strain rates up to 10^5/s. This testing is coupled to dynamic, high-speed TEM (DTEM) in order to obtain high speed imaging of the deformation and failure processes. These state-of the-art experimental techniques yield significant insights toward the understanding of high-strain rate mechanical behavior of metallic nanowires, dislocation processes in confined geometries, and validation of interatomic potentials for molecular dynamics (MD)-based modeling of metals. This validation is extremely beneficial to atomistic modeling, not only for mechanical characterization, but for a breadth of scientific disciplines where MD simulations are used to gain insights into chemical, electrical, and thermal material behavior.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objectives of this research project were to explore, for the first time, the mechanical response of sub-150 nm-diameter metallic nanowires, at high strain rates (up to 10^3/s), to elucidate the structure-property relationships, and to compare mechanical behaviors to bulk properties to gain insight into deformation mechanisms and failure operating at different size regimes.

One of the key findings from this project is the strain rate dependent brittle-to-ductile transition observed in bi-crystalline silver nanowires. By employing MEMS devices with low mass and electronically controlled actuation and load sensing, tensile tests at strain rates between 0.01/s and 2/s were performed. A remarkable rate dependent brittle-to-ductile transition was identified at a strain rate of approximately 0.2/s. Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) observation of the tested nanowires revealed that spatial distribution of plastic regions, along the nanowire, and dislocation densities increase with increasing strain rate. Given that nanostructures are envisioned in applications such as nanoelectromechanical systems (NEMS), where frequencies of operation range from tens of kHz to GHz, the elucidated rate dependent mechanical properties provide fundamental understanding needed in the design of high performance, robust, and failure-tolerant nanoelectronic systems.

 

Another project discovery deals with the mechanical integrity and robustness of nanoscale metallic materials subjected to cyclic and constant loading. It is common knowledge that a structure being stretched to and held at a stress level below its yield stress remains elastic and will not break. However, in situ electron microscopic mechanical testing on single crystal silver nanowires reveals that failure could occur at stress levels below yield, for a loading duration of hours, as a result of instabilities arising from atomic diffusion and nanowire morphological changes assisted by surface stresses. Cyclic loading (fatigue) did not reveal a different failure mode because the diffusion assisted instabilities dominated the nanostructure response. These findings have implications in the design of reliable and enduring flexible electronic devices, where metallic nanostructures serve as structural and electrical components, and their integrity under constant and cyclic loadings is essential. The results also deepen our understanding of the failure process of nanostructures and contributes to metallurgy in terms of possible ways to improve the composition and synthesis of nanowires.

 

While studies on the mechanical behavior of nanowires shed light on the deformation mechanisms at the nanoscale, its relationship to the behavior of bulk materials is not obvious. To study the latter, while preserving many of the advantages of nanoscale experiments such as simple and well-defined specimens, direct comparison to computational modelling, and ease of structural characterization, we conducted in situ electron microscopic experiments on silver micropillars with a diameter of 5 micrometers. We focus on achieving strain rates up to 100/s, because such experiments would enable direct comparison with discrete dislocation dynamic simulations. We established instrumentation to perform experiments with strain rate spanning six orders of magnitude and obtained stress-strain behaviors. Future efforts will be dedicated to the in-depth investigation of microstructural evolution and its link to rate dependent mechanical behavior.

 

In summary, through the support of this project, we have pioneered the experimental investigation of the dynamic mechanical behavior of nanoscale metallic materials. The studies covered strain rate regimes previously unexplored experimentally and the findings advanced our knowledge of deformation mechanisms and failure processes, in nanoscale metallic materials, which are critical to the development and optimization of miniaturized electronic devices and sensors. By pushing the limit of strain rates accessible in experiments, we are closing current gaps between experiments and atomistic simulations. This will be essential to validate atomistic models and employed force fields and in the process inform researchers on ways to improve models, which will ultimately lead to a greater ability to guide material design and performance predictions.

The project also provided opportunities for training several graduate students and postdocs working in the PI’s group, with several of them currently holding faculty positions. Participating students were involved in various mentorship roles including the mentorship of incoming graduate students, of minority backgrounds, and advising undergraduates in senior capstone projects and summer research experiences (REU program). The design of the in situ TEM mechanical testing platform is available to the community at large and as such is being adopted in labs around the world. Companies specializing in micro and nanoscale testing equipment are employing the MEMS concepts to develop new high strain rate testing platforms.


Last Modified: 07/02/2020
Modified by: Horacio D Espinosa

Images (1 of )
  • Brittle-to-ductile transition in bi-crystalline silver nanowires. (a) Using MEMS device, the strain rate accessible in experiment has been increased to bridge the gap between experiment and simulation. (b) Transition point in stress-strain curves is in good agreement with simulations.
    Horacio Espinosa
    Copyrighted
    Horacio D Espinosa
    Brittle-to-ductile transition
  • Failure of nanowires under constant loading. (a) Nanowires experience stress-relation and eventual failure under constant strain, and TEM images captures the defect evolution. (b) MD simulation and (c) theoretical model attribute the failure to stress-assisted atom migration and surface diffusion.
    Horacio Espinosa
    Horacio D Espinosa
    Reliability of stressed metallic nanostructures
  • (a) With an in situ testing setup, compression tests at different strain rates on silver micropillars are carried out. (b) Stress-strain curves and (c) TEM micrograph are used to develop a structure-behavior relationship, which will shed light on rate effect at microscale materials.
    Horacio Espinosa
    Horacio D Espinosa
    In situ high strain rate testing of micropillars
